Core damage frequency (CDF) is a probabilistic risk assessment (PRA) statistic that estimates the frequency of accidents that cause damage to the nuclear reactor core.1 Core damage is the worst thing that can happen to a nuclear reactor, as due to damage of this structure, the operator might lose control of the nuclear reaction, possibly leading to a meltdown.
An assessment of permanent or temporary changes in a nuclear power plant is performed to evaluate if such changes are within risk criteria. Risk measures, such as core damage frequency and large early release frequency (LERF), determine the risk criteria for such changes.
This risk analysis allows decision making of any changes within a nuclear power plant in accordance with legislation, safety margins and performance strategies.
In a 2003 study commissioned by the
European Commission
, the average core damage frequency of nuclear reactors was estimated at once in 20,000 reactor years, or 5 × 10−5.2 In a more recent 2008 study performed by the Electric Power Research Institute, the estimated core damage frequency for the
United States
nuclear industry is estimated at once in 50,000 reactor years, or 2 × 10−5.3
